sender.senderstreetaddress: Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corp. Bldg 419, One Health Plaza

reaction.primarysourcereaction: Left frontal Ischemic stroke due to heart disease (mitral regurgitation)
Renal dysfunction possibly due to dehydration/ Renal disfunction
Renal dysfunction possibly due to dehydration

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
Case number PHHO2011AR021780, is an initial report received on 30 Dec 2011, from clinical study CRAD001A2429. This 54-year-old female subject [centre number 0141, subject number 02] was enrolled in a 24-month, multi-center, open-label, randomized, controlled trial to investigate efficacy, safety and evolution of cardiovascular parameters in de novo renal transplant recipients after early calcineurin inhibitor to everolimus conversion.
Concomitant medication included Myfortic. On 16 Dec 2011, the subject underwent cadaveric renal transplant. On the same day, the subject started the study medications (tacrolimus) at a dose of 04 mg BID. The subject had no complications of renal transplant and was discharged on 27 Dec 2011 with creatinine 1.28 mg/dl. On 30 Dec 2011, the subject experienced renal dysfunction and leukocytosis. On unspecified date, the subject was re-hospitalized, creatinine was 1.8 mg/dl and white cell count was 19.000, urine culture resulted negative and chest radiograph was normal. The subject was on parenteral hydration (normal saline solution) from 30 Dec 2011 to 31 Dec 2011. On that date, laboratory tests performed showed creatinine 1.24 mg/dl, white cell count 11000 and neutrophils fraction 69%. The subject remained without fever. The outcome for events was reported as condition improving. On 31 Dec 2011, the subject was discharged from hospital. The subject received increased dose (10 mg) of study medication (Tacrolimus) (date unspecified). On 16 Jan 2012, the subject was hospitalized to perform renal transplant biopsy due to renal dysfunction (second occurrence). On the same date, creatinine was 2 mg/dl and white cell count was 13800u/mm3. Thorax X-ray was normal. On 16 Jan 2012, the subject started with fever and leukocytosis, without any clear source of infection. On 17 Jan 2012, creatinine raised to 2.11 mg/dl and urinary and blood culture were performed and resulted positive to Klebsiella pneumonia. On the same date, the subject started Ceftazidime treatment. On 19 Jan 2012, the subject started intravenous Imipenem (paracetamol). On 20 Jan 2012, creatinine was 3.75 mg/dl. On 23 Jan 2012, the subject presented right faciobrachial crural hemiparesia. On the same date, brain CT (computerized tomography) scan performed reported left frontal ischemic stroke (hypodense lesion in left frontal region). On 23 Jan 2012, the subject presented with aspiration pneumonia. On unspecified date, the subject was moved to ICU (intensive care unit), the fever persisted and vancomycin and metronidazole were added to treatment. The investigator reported that the subject had many compliance problems with study medication and it was decided to interrupt the treatment with study medication. On 24 Jan 2012, the subject took the last dose of Myfortic and the last dose of Tacrolimus on 25 Jan 2012. On that date, creatinine improved to 1.49 mg/dl and renal function improved. On 26 Jan 2012, the subject presented with acute tubulointerstitial nephritis (moderate). On 26 Jan 2012, creatinine was 1.55 mg/dl. On that date, the subject was considered recovered with sequelae from ischemic stroke (the subject had a mild improving neurological condition with stable hemodynamic profile). The subject switched the study medication Tacrolimus to Neoral on 26 Jan 2012. On 28 Jan 2012, the subject received the last dose of the study medication (Neoral). At the time of the report, the subject was improving from bacteremia and unchanged from ischemic stroke. The subject recovered with sequelae from renal dysfunction. On 28 Jan 2012, the subject experienced septic shock. On the same day, the subject died due to urinary tract infection and septic shock. The investigator reported that the according to death certificate, the cause of death was cardiac arrests. The investigator confirmed that an autopsy was not performed. The events were considered as serious by the investigator bacteremia and ischemic stroke (life threatening), renal dysfunction (both occurrences) (hospitalisation), urinary tract infection as serious (fatal and life threatening), septic shock and cardiac arrests as serious (Fatal). In the absence of investigator's seriousness criteria, Novartis safety physician assessed the event aspiration pneumonia as serious (hospitalization). The event of tubulointerstitial nephritis was considered as serious (medically significant) by the investigator.
The investigator did not suspect relationship between the events bacteremia, ischemic stroke, renal dysfunction possibly due to dehydration, septic shock and urinary tract infection and the study medication (tacrolimus and Myfortic). The investigator suspected a relation between the events (cardiac arrests, aspiration pneumonia) and the study medications (Neoral, Tacrolimus and Myfortic). In the absence of investigator causality the events cardiac arrest and septic shock were considered as suspected to Neoral for reporting purpose. The event renal dysfunction (both occurrences) was reportedly due to dehydration and the event left frontal Ischemic stroke due to heart disease (mitral regurgitation). The investigator did not suspect any relationship between the event of acute tubulointerstitial nephritis and the study medications.
Follow up received on 17 Jan 2012: Added event dehydration and fever, updated laboratory information, treatment drugs, event outcome and discharge date.
Follow up received on 26 Jan 2012, prior to circulation of previous report: Added events urinary tract infection, bacteremia and ischemic stroke. Updated laboratory tests, treatment, events outcome and seriousness criteria.
Follow-up report received on 19 Apr 2012: Updated additional events of septic shock, outcome, autopsy details, seriousness and causality.
Follow-up (DR) received on 05 Jun 2012: Updated causality of the event septic shock (not suspected to study medication).
Follow up received on 25 Jul 2012: Updated study medication (Neoral) information, causality and cause of death as per death certificate with autopsy details.
Follow up data reconciliation report received on 20 Nov 2012: Updated new event (aspiration pneumonia).
Follow up data reconciliation report received on 22 Nov 2012: Updated date of death in the case.
Follow up data reconciliation report received on 23 Nov 2012, prior to the circulation of the previous report on 22 Nov 2012: Upadted new diagnsis (acute tubulointerstitial nephritis) with onset, seriousness, causality and outcome.
Follow up DR received on 10 Dec 2012: Updated onset date of event septick shock.
summary.sendercomment:
For Prograf: Serious adverse drug reaction aspiration pneumonia, (medically significant), assessed as unlisted according to the Summary of product characteristics. Investigator causality is suspected.
Serious adverse drug reaction report, cardiac arrest (fatal), assessed as unlisted according to the Summary of product characteristics. Investigator causality is suspected.
MR comment: Based on review of available reported data, Novartis agrees with the investigator's causality for the reported events Urinary tract infection, Bacteremia, Ischemic stroke, Kidney dysfunction, and Dehydration as not suspected for all the suspected drugs, and Septic Shock as not suspected for mycophenolic acid and tacrolimus. Based on the available reported minimal information on the exact details of the event Cardiac arrest, the event is currently unassessable. The case will be reassessed when additional information becomes available.
